Award.AwardTitle: Superfluid Atomic Bosons, Fermions and Their Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of ultracold atomic physics has been progressing rapidly without signs of slowing down. Under this award, we will carry out a theoretical study of several important problems concerning the superfluid properties of cold atoms. These projects are of fundamental importance, and in the meantime are inspired by recent experimental progress in the field. We will consider the properties of cold atomic ensembles whose effective spatial dimensions in which they live are tuned. A tunable spatial dimension is not readily achievable in other materials. But for cold atoms, by adjusting the geometry of the trapping potential that is used to confine them, such a feat can be realized in the lab. We will also consider the novel properties of cold atoms under the manipulation of appropriately arranged laser fields. Under proper conditions, the laser beams can induce synthetic electromagnetic fields such that the neutral atoms behave like charged particles moving in electric and/or magnetic fields.

These research projects are of great relevance to current experiments, some of which are being carried out by PI's colleagues at Rice University. These problems span a quite wide spectrum within the field of cold atoms with close ties to condensed matter physics and nonlinear physics. Students involved in these projects will receive a solid training in theoretical physics, including both analytical methods and numerical techniques. Such a training will be very valuable for their future career in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award covers the period from 7/1/2012 to 6/30/2015. The main goal of this research is to advance our knowledge in ultracold atomic physics, which concerns the properties of atoms and molecules at extremely low temperature. At such low temperatures, atoms and molecules obey the rules set by quantum mechanics, which often exhibit characters that are counter-intuitive to our everyday experiences.  For example, these dilute atomic systems can become superfluid at sufficiently low temperatures, which share some common features with superconductors. Superconductors are conductors that can carry electricity without resistance, as such they may have a huge impact on our society. However, many important aspects of superconductors remain mysterious despite of the tremendous effort put into the study of these materials. By studying the much simpler ultracold atomic systems, we may hope that one day superconductors will be demystified.

 

Our research is theoretical in nature. However, they do have an impact on the experiments. Some of the works we did resulted from direct collaborations with experimental groups in our field. This is important as advances in the field rely on the mutual support between theory and experiment.  

 

Training of students and preparing them for their future career in science and technology sector represent a major aspect of the NSF-funded research. During this award period, two students successfully defended their Ph.D. theses and both are now working in industry, one student obtained his Master's degree and is now working towards his Ph.D. degree, and two undergraduates carried out their senior thesis research under my supervision and they are now pursuing their Ph.D. in physics at graduate schools.
